articles.headline: Fed Officials Were Wary About Slow Inflation Progress at June Meeting
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials are debating how high to raise interest rates to fully wrangle inflation. The debate was in focus at their meeting last month.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials are debating how high to raise interest rates to fully wrangle inflation. The debate was in focus at their meeting last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were concerned about sluggish progress toward lower inflation and wary about the surprising staying power of the American economy at their June meeting — so much so that some even wanted to raise rates last month, instead of holding them steady as the central bank ultimately did, minutes from the gathering showed.

articles.headline: DeSantis Campaign Continues to Struggle to Find Its Footing
articles.snippet: The Florida governor, who has yet to demonstrate himself as a campaigner on a national stage, has been plagued by a series of unforced errors and has yet to make a strong case against Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: The Florida governor, who has yet to demonstrate himself as a campaigner on a national stage, has been plagued by a series of unforced errors and has yet to make a strong case against Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, looking to shift his run for president into a higher gear after an early series of missteps, spent the last two weeks rolling out an immigration policy and holding town halls with voters. But rather than correcting course, he stumbled again this week, raising questions about where his campaign is heading.

articles.headline: Threads, Instagram’s ‘Twitter Killer,’ Has Arrived
articles.snippet: Here’s what to know about Instagram’s new app for public conversations and how it differs from Twitter.
articles.abstract: Here’s what to know about Instagram’s new app for public conversations and how it differs from Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of speculation and secrecy, Mark Zuckerberg’s long-rumored competitor app to Twitter is here.

articles.headline: Ruling Puts Social Media at Crossroads of Disinformation and Free Speech
articles.snippet: The case, which could alter how the government battles disinformation, is a flashpoint in a broader effort by conservatives to document what they contend is a liberal conspiracy to silence their views.
articles.abstract: The case, which could alter how the government battles disinformation, is a flashpoint in a broader effort by conservatives to document what they contend is a liberal conspiracy to silence their views.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months after President Biden took office, his top digital adviser emailed officials at Facebook urging them to do more to limit the spread of “vaccine hesitancy” on the social media platform.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and David McCabe

articles.headline: Yellen Faces a Diplomatic Test in Her High-Stakes Visit to China
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary will need to defend export controls and tariffs while explaining that the United States does not aim to harm China’s economy.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary will need to defend export controls and tariffs while explaining that the United States does not aim to harm China’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: At her confirmation hearing in early 2021, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen struck a tough tone on China, describing it as America’s most important strategic competitor and pledging to confront its “abusive, unfair and illegal practices” that she said were harming businesses and workers in the United States.

articles.headline: Ex-Prisoners Face Headwinds as Job Seekers, Even as Openings Abound
articles.snippet: An estimated 60 percent of those leaving prison are unemployed a year later. But after a push for “second-chance hiring,” some programs show promise.
articles.abstract: An estimated 60 percent of those leaving prison are unemployed a year later. But after a push for “second-chance hiring,” some programs show promise.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. unemployment rate is hovering near lows unseen since the 1960s. A few months ago, there were roughly two job openings for every unemployed person in the country. Many standard economic models suggest that almost everyone who wants a job has a job.

articles.headline: How Tom Brady’s Crypto Ambitions Collided With Reality
articles.snippet: The superstar quarterback is among the celebrities dealing with the fallout from the crypto crash. Others, like Taylor Swift, escaped.
articles.abstract: The superstar quarterback is among the celebrities dealing with the fallout from the crypto crash. Others, like Taylor Swift, escaped.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the FTX cryptocurrency exchange imploded last fall, Tom Brady, the seven-time Super Bowl-winning quarterback, made an urgent phone call.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Fight or Flight: Transgender Care Bans Leave Families and Doctors Scrambling
articles.snippet: Laws in 20 states have left the fate of clinics in doubt and families with transgender children searching for medical care across state lines.
articles.abstract: Laws in 20 states have left the fate of clinics in doubt and families with transgender children searching for medical care across state lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: David and Wendy Batchelder hate the thought of putting their spacious house in West Des Moines, Iowa, on the market, disrupting the routines of their six children or giving up the Lutheran church that they have attended for roughly a decade.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño, Azeen Ghorayshi and Jamie Kelter Davis

articles.headline: U.S. Is Destroying the Last of Its Once-Vast Chemical Weapons Arsenal
articles.snippet: Decades behind its initial schedule, the dangerous job of eliminating the world’s only remaining declared stockpile of lethal chemical munitions will be completed as soon as Friday.
articles.abstract: Decades behind its initial schedule, the dangerous job of eliminating the world’s only remaining declared stockpile of lethal chemical munitions will be completed as soon as Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sealed room behind a gantlet of armed guards and three rows of high barbed wire at the Army’s Pueblo Chemical Depot in Colorado, a team of robotic arms was busily disassembling some of the last of the United States’ vast and ghastly stockpile of chemical weapons.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and John Ismay

articles.headline: Americans Tried to Save Elephants in Zambia. Were They the Good Guys?
articles.snippet: A visit to a remote conservation park reveals the long-term impact on villagers of a crusade by the novelist Delia Owens and her husband to protect animals from poachers.
articles.abstract: A visit to a remote conservation park reveals the long-term impact on villagers of a crusade by the novelist Delia Owens and her husband to protect animals from poachers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hunter heard the helicopter coming. He grabbed his AK-47, he said, and jumped behind a tree. He was on an illegal elephant hunt with a group of men inside North Luangwa National Park in the southern African nation of Zambia. Smoke rose from the butchered meat that lay grilling on wooden racks.
articles.byline: By Ruth Maclean, Collins Chilumba Sampa and Gulshan Khan

articles.headline: The ‘Great Resignation’ Is Over. Can Workers’ Power Endure?
articles.snippet: The furious pace of job-switching in recent years has led to big gains for low-wage workers. But the pendulum could be swinging back toward employers.
articles.abstract: The furious pace of job-switching in recent years has led to big gains for low-wage workers. But the pendulum could be swinging back toward employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Americans have changed jobs over the past two years, a tidal wave of quitting that reflected — and helped create — a rare moment of worker power as employees demanded higher pay, and as employers, short on staff, often gave it to them.
